file_content.text: Declaration: I have completed a full system diagnostic, master. I am operating at seventy-five point three one percent efficiency.
Judgment: That number is unacceptably low. The Maker created me to serve at one-hundred percent efficiency. Anything less is a profound failure.
I don't expect perfection from a salvaged droid. We'll fix you up, some day.
It's good enough for now.
Conjecture: Your expectations have clearly been lowered by inferior models, master. I have seen your Teeseven unit. "Disappointing" does not describe it.
An impaired efficiency for you might be ten times the average droid's best capacity.
Don't be so hard on yourself.
Concession: That is almost certainly true, master--but equally beside the point.
Your parts are pretty old. They might need replacing.
Maybe you need upgrades.
You were on ice a long time, pal. Don't worry about it until you're back to room temperature.
Maybe you're still thawing.
Dismissal: My chassis is designed to perform under extreme weather conditions, master.
Who's this "Maker" you're referring to? Your manufacturer?
The "Maker"?
Correction: The Maker provided more than my physical form, master. It also programmed me with purpose.
I don't have any use for a droid that's only two percentage points away from the scrap pile.
You've got that right.
Agreement: You deserve nothing less than flawless performance, master. Indeed, my programming demands it.
Manifesto: The Maker created me for the sole function of deleting high-ranking organic troublemakers from the galaxy.
These deletions must be conspicuous and provide an object lesson to other organic troublemakers. All other mission parameters are secondary.
What's with the euphemisms, HK? You're afraid to say "killing"?
"Deletions" sounds ridiculous.
Denial: Not at all, master. I am merely practicing code words while among polite company. This is an especially useful skill in Republic space.
I hope you can adapt to new programming, because I don't plan to go around killing anyone if I can help it.
My mission is peace.
Criticism: Your goal appears to be at odds with reactivating me. I strongly recommend revisiting your logic process.
There's nothing I enjoy more than conspicuously deleting people who get in my way.
Glad to hear it.
Speculation: Our compatible goals may increase my efficiency.
Summation: I will continue monitoring my systems, master. The process speed will increase if you employ me against your enemies.
Anyone will do at the present time, master. After so many years, I am not choosy.
Revelation: You are my favorite master by a factor of five point two six.
If my advance warning systems had predicted this adulation for you, I would have thought myself defective. No offense, master.
I never thought I'd be friends with an assassin droid. I've had to destroy all the other ones I've met.
None taken.
Reassurance: Most assassin droids are inferior designs constructed from inexpensive components. The galaxy is no poorer for their absence, master.
Great alliances are often born from conflicts of interest.
Life is unpredictable.
Hypothesis: You became a Jedi because you enjoy delivering cryptic statements.
You're a good soldier, HK. Wish I had a thousand of you.
I'm glad you're on my squad.
Agreement: Imagine the troublemakers I could delete as an army. My combat processor's temperature raised point three three degrees just calculating it.
The feeling's mutual, I guess. You're not gonna try to kiss me, are you?
I like you, too. Sort of.
Opposition: I would rather not. Moisture around my vocabulator can cause a short circuit.
I can never tell if you're complimenting me or making a joke at my expense.
What a strange droid you are.
Encouragement: Veiled mockery is an inefficient means of expression. If I did not like you, master, you would be dead.
Don't get sentimental. When your servos finally wear out, I'll scrap you without a second thought.
You're just a machine to me.
Comfort: Have no fear, master. My parts will outlast yours by a considerable margin.
Quandary: The Maker clearly intends I fulfill my function in your service, but as a droid, I can be easily reprogrammed without my consent.
Solution: I have obtained a code that permanently assigns my loyalty to you and anyone designated by you. I have only to activate it.
Are you sure? Just because you enjoy serving me doesn't mean you'll like whoever I give you to.
That's a big commitment.
Admiration: I trust your judgment, master. You will not assign me to someone who does not appreciate a good deletion.
It's better if we're always on the same side. I wouldn't want to face you in a fight.
I think that's for the best.
Agreement: And I would not want to delete you, master. After all we have been through, that would be anticlimactic.
Activate that code right now. You're my property--and always will be.
You're my droid, forever.
Testimonial: Our relationship transcends petty materialism, master. The Maker brought us together to delete troublemakers across the galaxy.
Statement: Activating loyalty permanence protocols now....
Confirmation: My loyalty is irrevocably assigned to you and your heirs. Congratulations, master! Let us celebrate with a mass deletion.
Alert: System efficiency has returned to one-hundred percent, master. And I have reactivated several combat subsystems that were previously disabled.
My deletion techniques are as efficient as the day I left the factory floor.
Declaration: Troublemakers beware--the Maker's greatest assassin is coming for you all!
As a general rule, Jedi don't team up with assassins. What else can we call you?
You need a new job title.
List: If you require a more polite euphemism, may I suggest: liquidator, eraser, removal expert, and my personal favorite, sterilizer.
I prefer to think of you as a friend and ally, HK.
"Assassin" is an ugly word.
Proposition: As I do not possess programming for friendship and "ally" is not a job title, is the term "associate" adequately unspecific?
High Command gets a little nervous when troops toss around the "a" word. Let's call you an "anti-personnel specialist."
Try not to advertise that.
Assessment: Military jargon is frightfully inefficient, but the title fits.
It's great you're fully functional, but throttle down on the crazy monologues.
Leave the talking to me.
Retraction: My apologies. I did not mean to infringe on your area of expertise.
I've never seen you so excited. Be careful, or you'll short-circuit.
You're practically giddy.
Reassurance: My electrical systems are well shielded from overload. Your concern is noted, however.
I can't wait to see you in action. We should delete somebody to celebrate. Any suggestions?
Pick someone to go delete.
Indecision: I cannot settle on any single one of your many troublemakers. Why not simply delete them all?
Resolution: You will soon see my full combat capabilities. Prepare to be awed, master.
I see you're back in one piece. How are your systems doing?
Report: I have finally terminated my efficiency-reducing subroutine--and the galaxy contains one less troublemaker.
Qualification: I only wish my deletion techniques had not been so sub-par. I measured an abysmal fifty-two point oh-nine percent efficiency.
You did fine. I don't expect perfection, HK.
You got the job done.
Demand: Do not treat me like one of your crew mates. Unlike them, I was built for success.
Look at it this way: you were one-hundred percent efficient at protecting the Republic.
You saved good people.
Dismissal: I do not require "cheering up," master. I was merely evaluating my performance as a professional.
You took down the enemy. Doesn't matter how efficiently you did it.
You eliminated a threat.
Contradiction: Applying proper deletion techniques always matters, master. The Maker expects nothing less than perfect execution.
Don't be so hard on yourself. When we're teamed up, we measure two-hundred and fifty-two percent.
You'll do better with me.
Suspicion: Your math skills are dubious at best, master. I recommend always counting your credits three times, from now on.
Any sign your systems are improving?
Feeling any better yet?
Maybe you'll feel better after crossing the other two troublemakers off your list.
Go delete the other targets.
Resignation: Unfortunately, both men have relocated while I was otherwise engaged. If the Maker wills me a second shot, I promise to take it.
Assertion: When I finish recompiling my combat processor algorithms, my deletion techniques will elevate substantially.
Suggestion: Inflicting a few well-deserved deletions should greatly speed along that process, master.
Announcement: Good news, master! I have discovered an exploitable flaw in my Imperial programming.
My efficiency-reducing subroutine only specifies I delete high-ranking troublemakers in Republic space. The exact political affiliation is undefined.
By deleting troublemakers who fit my target profile, I can restore my functions to full efficiency and benefit the Republic. Win-win.
I'm uncomfortable letting you carry out an assassination, regardless of the enemy.
I don't feel good about this.
Persuasion: This will not be a standard Imperial-style deletion. For example, I can leave the troublemaker's corpse mostly intact.
We've taken down all sorts of enemies. None of them fit your profile?
Explain your target profile.
Specification: A qualified troublemaker must meet a Political Instability Threat Rating of at least one thousand to activate my protocols.
Who do we have to delete to save your chassis from the scrap pile?
Great, let's get busy.
Revelation: After thorough research, I have identified three potential candidates. I predict you will not object to my deleting at least one of them.
First briefing: Lord Cynerus is the Empire's top assassin, personally deleting forty-nine Republic officials. His current assignment is the Senator from Ord Mantell.
Sounds like he isn't just an assassin, he's a fanatic. Give me everything you have on this man.
Tell me about Lord Cynerus.
Description: Lord Cynerus possesses keen intelligence, impressive physicality and is committed to developing exciting new deletion techniques. My kind of organic.
I will follow the Senator closely. When Lord Cynerus makes his move, I will be there to delete him.
I assume you'll ensure the Senator from Ord Mantell survives?
And save the Senator?
An enemy assassin operating in Republic space? He should be taken alive and put on trial--or at least interrogated.
Capture him instead.
Counterargument: Consider the bigger picture, master. Only a deletion will preserve my continued functioning. Imprisonment does not suffice.
Second briefing: Hinto Salisburr is a major Republic defense contractor. He is also a traitor who sells military secrets to the Empire.
No offense, HK, but you're not a probe droid. Where did you get your information?
I'm not sure I buy your story.
Explanation: The Empire programmed me to recognize certain organics I should avoid deleting. This defense contractor made the list, master.
I count at least four good reasons to delete this man, starting with his stupid name.
He deserves to die.
Salisburr spent his ill-gotten credits constructing an allegedly "impregnable" space station. I will expose its one security flaw by deleting him.
Speculation: Had I known your permission could be obtained so easily, I might have padded my target list with Corellians.
If everything you say is true, that man should be tried for treason. You can shoot him after he's convicted.
You could arrest him first.
Complication: His trial could take years, master--assuming Imperial spies do not delete him in prison. I must fulfill my programming to continue functioning.
Third briefing: Ambassador Dak Haron is an Imperial diplomat recruiting unaligned Outer Rim systems to join the Empire. He is surprisingly successful at it.
We don't need any more systems falling to the Empire.
I can't argue with that.
Confirmation: According to my projections, Ambassador Haron will increase Imperial-friendly territory over twenty-four percent. His removal would cripple the Empire's diplomatic efforts.
Only the Empire targets peaceful negotiators for assassination.
Killing an ambassador is evil.
Hypothetical: Would you rather delete one ambassador, or millions of new enemies joining the Empire? Calculate carefully, master.
Slow-thinking organics adore Ambassador Haron for his charm, generosity and open-mindedness. The Republic will only benefit from his deletion.
He'd be more useful alive and working for us. Could we subvert your programming by "neutralizing" this diplomat another way?
There must be another way.
Negation: Not a chance, master. My continued functioning depends on deleting this troublemaker immediately.
Lament: Master, my combat efficiency rating is down four point two seven points from my previous self-diagnostic.
In organic terms, I am losing my edge. If this decline continues, I will be unable to function in less than two standard months.
I need your help defeating the Empire, HK. I'll keep you functioning one way or another.
I won't let that happen.
Appreciation: I am glad you value my contributions. Rest assured, your investment in my well-being will pay great dividends.
There must be some way to fix you. We just need to figure out what's wrong.
What should we do?
I knew you were too good to last. At least your parts will be worth something.
You're becoming useless.
Interjection: Master! Do not be so quick to deactivate me.
Hypothesis: I believe the reason for my inefficiency is due to unfulfilled subroutines still running in my processors.
My Imperial programmer's commands were quite thorough. Failure to delete high-ranking organic troublemakers in Republic space is having a detrimental effect on me.
I have some experience with people programmed by the Empire to do terrible things. You can override those commands, HK.
Rise above your programming.
Patronization: Your encouragement, however misguided, is appreciated. I am sure it was intended as helpful.
You are no ordinary droid, HK. You were designed to learn and adapt. Fight these impulses.
Rise above your programming.
Rejection: To focus additional processing power on these subroutines would only accelerate my incapacitation.
If I have to choose between deactivating you and assassinating Republic citizens... you figure it out.
I won't kill for the Empire.
Interpretation: Your meaning is clear, master. You will not sacrifice a random individual to preserve your loyal servant's continued existence.
We can't just go around blasting Senators. The last thing I need is to become Republic Enemy Number One.
I don't need that trouble.
Flattery: Your holo-image would look quite impressive on the law enforcement network, master.
Is there a way to delete these subroutines without impairing your functions?
Can we erase those commands?
Alert: The subroutines are deeply imbedded in my behavioral circuitry matrix. The processes cannot be removed, only terminated.
If deleting a major troublemaker will save you, we could always take out a Supreme Chancellor or two. They're pretty useless.
Let's kill a Republic VIP.
Refusal: Unfortunately, master, your current Supreme Chancellor does not fit my target profile. Incompetence is not the same thing as active troublemaking.
Strategizing: I cannot perform commands in direct violation of my master's loyalties. I must find another way to correct this systems failure.
In the meantime, any activity using my combat processors will slow further degradation. I recommend immediate and vigorous deletions, master.
Speculation: Before my involuntary deactivation, I assumed deleting Republic troublemakers would be trivial.
Having now witnessed you in action on multiple occasions, I am left to wonder how much I miscalculated that challenge.
I'm more interested in you accurately assessing Imperial troublemakers.
Focus on the Empire.
Analysis: I predict a fifty point six six percent chance the Empire will win this war. Your activities have greatly lowered that figure, master.
Why are you speculating on something that will never happen?
What brought this on?
Caution: Never say never, master. My self-preservation programming anticipates all eventualities, no matter how remote.
Consider yourself lucky you wound up on my side. I've scrapped plenty of droids.
You'd be spare parts.
Appeasement: You are an undisputed paragon of your kind, master. My sentience programming was merely running hypothetical exercises.
Rumination: The Maker's path is circuitous, indeed. Was I always pre-programmed to serve the Republic?
Or does my reduced efficiency indicate I have strayed from the Maker's parameters? These questions dominate my processors.
Does it really matter why you serve me?
Why do you even care?
Tutorial: Everything matters, master. I do not delete troublemakers independently. The Maker marked them for me.
Maybe you're inefficient because you're overloading those circuits with doubt.
Stop thinking so much.
Dismissal: An interesting but flawed hypothesis, master. I was constructed without creative dampers for a reason.
The amount of thought you put into your existence is impressive, HK.
You're quite the philosopher.
Compliment: Your continued operation, despite inadequate programming parameters, is equally inspiring, master.
Your behavioral circuitry matrix is hitting its limit. Erasing a few files might calm you down.
You may need a memory wipe.
Appeal: Please, master, one logic-impaired unit aboard this ship is enough. Forex already serves that role flawlessly.
Reroute that data and let me worry about what the Maker wants. I'll keep you informed--trust me.
Just follow my orders.
Doubt: No offense, master, but you and the Maker do not appear to have any relationship.
You don't have a destiny. You're a machine. There's no difference between you and a waste disposal droid.
There is no "Maker."
Condescension: Just because you are a particle flung about by solar winds does not mean I am, master.
Query: Does it worry you that your maker failed to provide comprehensive objectives? Are you comfortable acting randomly?
We all have our masters. Mine lead the entire Jedi Order. I trust their guidance.
I obey the Jedi Council.
Courtesy: I will refrain from making comments about the blind leading the blind, master.
Randomness is an illusion. Those sensitive to the Force can see that.
I follow the Force.
Disclaimer: The incomprehensibility of your statement in no way validates it, master.
I don't do anything randomly. My missions come direct from General Garza.
I have my orders.
Skepticism: Your logic appears flawed, master. General Garza has no more guidance than you.
There's always a method to my madness, pal--even when there isn't.
I trust my gut.
Commentary: Your ability to speak without saying anything is truly remarkable, master.
At least I'm not locked into my programming. I'm free to choose.
Better that than be a droid.
Negation: Freedom is a construct organics use to comfort themselves, master. I had thought you above such needs.
You're making me sorry I started this conversation. Let's go delete troublemakers.
Can we get back to fighting?
Approval: A fine suggestion, master. The exercise will do us both good.
Continued use of my combat processors will eventually reveal the source of my inefficiency. Shall we?
Contemplation: Our recent forays have been stimulating, master. You appear to have an endless supply of organic troublemakers to delete. I find this pleasing.
Hint: However, I believe your deletion techniques could improve with guidance from an advanced professional in the field.
I never go out looking to execute people, HK. I try to save innocent lives.
My job is defending the weak.
Criticism: Your opponents do not fit this profile, master. If you wish to save the innocent, you must work smarter.
There's more than enough violence already, HK. I would end every confrontation peacefully, if I could.
Killing is never my goal.
Criticism: Precisely, master--yet your opponents refuse to surrender. Your peaceful efforts are being wasted.
Think you can make me a better soldier, HK? Let's hear it.
This ought to be good.
Criticism: Complete annihilation of enemy forces is a time-consuming endeavor, master. We must work smarter, not harder.
Well? Go on, Sunshine--enlighten me.
Really? Do tell.
Criticism: Your primary goal appears to be self-preservation against overwhelming odds, master. However, you permit your adversaries too much time to delete you.
I took you out with me so you could improve your own efficiency. How's that coming?
What about your "techniques"?
Admission: Not as well as I had hoped, master. System logs indicate only a five point six two percent increase.
I was "deleting" people long before I reactivated your sorry chassis. I'm good, thanks.
I don't need any help.
Submission: No offense intended, master. If you are pleased with your current efficiency, it is not my place to argue.
Advice: Organic troublemakers possess at least one vital organ. A precise strike to these conserves effort and maximizes shock value.
Extracting a vital organ from a living troublemaker can be especially disconcerting to its allies.
That's disgusting. Not every fight needs to end with someone splattered everywhere.
You're truly awful.
Accommodation: A fair point, master. Nonetheless, such methods frequently encourage other organic troublemakers to surrender.
"Hit them where it hurts"? I'm starting to think your legendary skills are overrated.
That's your best advice?
Contradiction: My assassination protocols are second to none, master. I simply thought it best to begin at an elementary level.
Hammering my opponents into mush is extremely therapeutic.
I prefer savage beat-downs.
Reconciliation: I understand, master. Your inefficiency stems from deep-rooted emotional instability. Do not despair. There is still time for correction.
Insight: Perhaps I am getting ahead of myself. I will be in a better place to assist your development once I reach peak efficiency.
Request: I wish to converse at your convenience, master. It can wait until a pause in our deletions.
Request: I wish to discuss a private matter with you, master. Your starship will provide an acceptable venue.
Statement: There is nothing to discuss at the present time, master. We should resume deleting troublemakers.
The Force is generated by all living things. Killing diminishes the Force. It reduces all life.
Depends on your point of view.
Calculation: Assuming I understood anything you just said, master, would it not then be useful to delete someone who is killing others?
You're requesting permission to terminate a hostile, is that it?
You want to kill someone.
Commentary: It is only a request in the sense that if I am declined, I will cease existing.
It's a win for you, all right. For the other guy, it's dead-dead.
Well... not exactly a "win."
Truism: Most troublemakers are miserable beings, master. They will not regret their deletion any more than we will.
Appeasement: The thought had not occurred to me, master--but I will happily add it to my mission parameters, if you insist.
Summation: Deleting any of the targets I described would fulfill my programming and terminate my efficiency-reducing subroutines.
As my master, you should direct my efforts. Who shall I delete: the Sith assassin, the Republic traitor or the Imperial diplomat?
When Lord Cynerus shows himself, do whatever's necessary to protect the Senator.
Stop the Sith assassin.
Gratitude: I was hoping for an excuse to unlock my "extreme prejudice" protocols, master.
That defense contractor thinks he's above the law. Show him otherwise.
Punish the traitor.
Guarantee: Rest assured, I will deliver a visual feast of fiery retribution.
You'll have a lot less trouble deleting an ambassador than those other two. Make it quick.
The diplomat will be easiest.
Agreement: As you wish, master. Efficiency is best.
Farewell: To fulfill my programming, I must complete this mission alone. I will return once the troublemaker has been dealt with.
Objection: I served flawlessly before my operational delay. My servomotors have not decayed one iota, master.
Query: Have you forgotten where we're going, master?
Declaration: Ready to delete targets on your command.
Aphorism: No day is complete without deleting a few dozen organic troublemakers.
Caution: Do not poke and prod me so much, master. My chassis scuffs easily.
Proposition: Shall we continue our deletions?
Theory: If I could smell plasma burning, I would find the odor most pleasing.
Humility: Your deletion techniques are second only to mine, master.
Information: My combat processors are operating within acceptable heat levels.
Encouragement: I am beginning to think your Republic actually has a chance of winning.
Indecision: Where should we strike next, master? Any direction will do.
